results.title: What Our Beech Tree Teaches Us About the Possibility of the Future
results.abstract: The idea of a “new normal” steals from us the possibility of being transformed, for better or worse.

media.caption: A beech tree in the author’s backyard in Providence, R.I.

results.adx_keywords: your-feed-health;your-feed-healthcare;Bacteria;Leprosy (Hansen's Disease);Armadillos;Research;Disabilities;Emerging Infectious Diseases (Journal);Florida
results.title: Leprosy May Be Endemic in Central Florida, Scientists Report
results.abstract: Still, there are fewer than 200 cases nationally each year, and the numbers have fallen significantly from the peak decades ago.

media.caption: Leprosy, also known as Hansen’s disease, is caused by slow-growing bacteria called Mycobacterium leprae. About 95 percent of people are genetically resistant to the bacteria.

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Actors and Actresses;Television;Movies;Margolis, Mark (1939-2023)
results.title: Mark Margolis, Scene-Stealing Actor in ‘Breaking Bad,’ Dies at 83
results.abstract: His character, an ex-drug lord in a wheelchair, was unable to speak, but Mr. Margolis, who also appeared in “Better Call Saul,” didn’t need dialogue to wield fearsome power.

media.caption: Mark Margolis in a scene from “Breaking Bad.” He played the former drug kingpin Hector Salamanca, who communicated by means of a wheelchair bell while living in a New Mexico nursing home.

results.adx_keywords: internal-sub-only;Content Type: Personal Profile;Women's Rights;Women and Girls;Pregnancy and Childbirth;Tests and Examinations;Abortion;Discrimination;Rural Areas;Menstruation;Jaglan, Sunil;Haryana (India);India
results.title: Where ‘No One Wanted Girls,’ a Dad in India Takes On the Patriarchy
results.abstract: A delivery room epiphany transformed a village headman into an unlikely and highly successful campaigner against prenatal sex testing, which often led to aborting female fetuses.

media.caption: Sunil Jaglan, center, discussing health issues with women in a farming village in Haryana State in India, where he has led a campaign against prenatal sex testing.
media.copyright: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times

results.byline: By Lauren McCarthy and Johnny Diaz
results.title: 4,000 Rescued Beagles, Bred for Research, Found Homes and Best Friends
results.abstract: The dogs, held in cages at a breeding and research facility, were bound for labs. About 4,000 were saved and, almost a year later, many are thriving with their families.

media.caption: Maple, who is 4, loves sunbathing and belly rubs. She was sitting in a yard in Dublin, Va.

results.adx_keywords: Jazz;Museums;Historic Buildings and Sites;Archives and Records;Content Type: Personal Profile;Armstrong, Louis;Moran, Jason (1975- );Armstrong, Louis, House Museum;Corona (Queens, NY)
results.title: Satchmo’s Wonderful World: Louis Armstrong Center Amplifies An Artist’s Vision
results.abstract: New jazz and exhibition spaces, and an inaugural show curated by Jason Moran, feature the trumpeter’s history, collaged onto the walls.

media.caption: Large circular vitrines inside the new Louis Armstrong Center hold artifacts from Armstrong’s 60,000-piece archive, including 700 tapes that were once housed miles away at Queens College. Jason Moran has curated the first permanent exhibition, “Here to Stay.”
media.copyright: Ike Edeani for The New York Times

results.title: Switched at Birth, Two Canadians Discover Their Roots at 67
results.abstract: Two Canadian men who were switched at birth to families of different ethnicities are now questioning who they really are and learning how racial heritage shapes identities.

media.copyright: Alana Paterson for The New York Times; Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York Times

results.title: Texas A&M Agrees to $1 Million Settlement With Journalism Professor
results.abstract: A university report found that fears of a conservative backlash botched the effort to hire a Black professor, Kathleen McElroy, to run its journalism program.

media.caption: Kathleen McElroy in June, when she was named director of Texas A&M University’s Department of Communication and Journalism.

results.adx_keywords: your-feed-science;Black People;DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid);Research;Cemeteries;Genetics and Heredity;Forced Labor;Slavery (Historical);Archaeology and Anthropology;Genealogy;Human Trafficking;Gates, Henry Louis Jr;Science (Journal);Maryland;United States
results.title: Enslaved African Americans in Maryland Linked to 42,000 Living Relatives
results.abstract: The analysis marks the first time historical DNA has been used to trace the descendants and distant cousins of enslaved people, researchers said.

media.caption: In 1979, construction on a highway expansion revealed human remains at the Catoctin Furnace in Maryland. Archaeologists uncovered 35 graves.

results.adx_keywords: United States Defense and Military Forces;Espionage and Intelligence Services;Zhao, Wenheng;Wei, Jinchao (Patrick);Justice Department;United States Navy;San Diego (Calif);Ventura County (Calif);China
results.byline: By Adam Goldman and Jill Cowan
results.title: Two U.S. Navy Sailors Charged With Helping China
results.abstract: Prosecutors said the two sailors in California gave Chinese intelligence officers U.S. military secrets and sensitive information.
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

media.caption: One of the two Navy sailors accused of spying was assigned to a ship based at Naval Base San Diego. The charges appear to reflect the Chinese government’s deep interest in the U.S. Navy’s Pacific Fleet.

results.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Finbarr O’Reilly
results.title: ‘It’s Crazy’: The Scramble for Ancient Treasures After Ukraine’s Dam Disaster
results.abstract: After the Kakhovka dam was blown up in June, the reservoir above it quickly drained, revealing a bonanza of artifacts that has electrified Ukrainian archaeologists.

media.copyright: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Lighting;Pop and Rock Music;Content Type: Personal Profile;vis-photo;internal-sub-only;Kuroda, Chris;Anastasio, Trey;Phish (Music Group)
results.title: How Phish’s Lighting Designer Jams With the Band
results.abstract: Chris Kuroda has brought more than 1,750 of the group’s shows to life since 1989, handling one of the most complex gigs in the business: responding in real time, without a set list.

media.caption: “I can’t wait to hear something before I execute the lighting cue,” Kuroda said. “I need to execute the lighting cue anticipating what’s going to happen.”
media.copyright: Balarama Heller for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Voyager Project;Space and Astronomy;Solar System;Research;your-feed-science;National Aeronautics and Space Administration;Jet Propulsion Laboratory
results.title: NASA Reaches Voyager 2 With a Last-Ditch ‘Shout’ Across the Void
results.abstract: After an erroneous command sent the spacecraft’s antenna askew, mission specialists hatched a plan to point it back toward Earth.

media.caption: The Canberra Deep Space Communication Complex in Australia sent the equivalent of an interstellar “shout” more than 12.5 billion miles to Voyager 2. Thirty-seven hours later, mission controllers learned that the command had worked.

results.title: Anger Builds in Towns Deliberately Flooded, in Part, to Save Beijing
results.abstract: A provincial leader set off an outcry by urging cities to serve as a “moat” for the capital, as diverted floodwaters sent scores of residents fleeing.

results.byline: By Paul Sonne and Valeriya Safronova
results.title: Jailed Russian Opposition Leader Navalny Receives New Sentence of 19 Years
results.abstract: Aleksei A. Navalny, who is already in prison, was sentenced for supporting “extremism,” amid intensified suppression of dissent in Russia.

media.caption: Aleksei A. Navalny, second from the left, appearing at a Moscow City Court hearing with his lawyers via video link on Friday.
